title: Grade 10 English Language Arts
teaser: Students analyze literary and journalistic nonfiction as well as poetry, drama, and fiction.

children.title: Reading Closely, Writing to Analyze:  Authors Develop Complex Characters, Ideas
children.teaser: Students engage with literature and nonfiction texts.

children.title: We Cannot Go to the Country
children.teaser: Students engage in close reading, annotating text, and evidence-based discussion and writing.

children.title: Annotation, Analysis, and Central Idea
children.teaser: Students explore Christopher Marlowe and are introduced to Accountable Independent Reading and annotation.

children.title: Promises and Pastoral Imagery
children.teaser: Students establish a foundational understanding of pastoral poetry and practice their annotation skills.

children.title: The Conversation Continues
children.teaser: Students explore the central ideas of Raleigh’s poems.  The Speaking and Listening Rubric are introduced.

children.title: Relationship Between Central Ideas in the Two Poems
children.teaser: Students explore both poems and focus on structural choices, understanding the central ideas in them.

children.title: Another Country Heard From
children.teaser: Students explore how a contemporary voice transforms the conversation begun by Marlowe and Raleigh.

children.title: Analyzing a Shared Idea
children.teaser: Students gather evidence about Williams’ transformation of Marlowe and Raleigh’s central ideas.

children.title: Using Evidence to Support a Claim: Writing Across the Texts
children.teaser: Students participate in a collaborative brainstorm in preparation for their independent written response.

children.title: For One Does Not Alter History Without Conviction
children.teaser: Students continue to consider how authors develop central ideas.

children.title: Complex Relationships: Hundert and Sedgewick
children.teaser: Students are introduced to two of the narrator’s relationships.  They revisit annotation techniques.

children.title: Confrontation and Changing Relationships
children.teaser: Students further explore the narrator’s character.  They cite textual evidence as they analyze character development.

children.title: Mr. Julius Caesar: The Development of a Central Idea
children.teaser: Students investigate the narrator’s decisions and how they contribute to developing a central idea.

children.title: Analyzing Conflict
children.teaser: Students explore the conflict the narrator feels.  They analyze character motivations with textual evidence.

children.title: Figurative Language and Word Choice
children.teaser: Students focus on figurative language and word choice, analyzing their impact on the text.

children.title: Analyzing Conflict's Role in Developing a Central Idea
children.teaser: Students analyze how challenges and word choice contributes helps advance the plot.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment
children.teaser: Students analyze how the narrator has developed throughout the text, citing supporting evidence.

children.title: Retirement, Rematch, and Reaction
children.teaser: Students analyze the impact of the narrator’s reflection, regret, and self-doubt on the decisions he makes for his future.

children.title: How do the Interactions Between Characters Develop Central Ideas?
children.teaser: Students engage in an evidence-based discussion to analyze the narrator’s reflections and interactions with former students.

children.title: Comparisons and Characterization
children.teaser: Students explore how the impact of the narrator develops a central idea of the text.

children.title: Identity, Expectations, and the Importance of History
children.teaser: Students analyze the narrator’s expectations of the reunion competition and how they clash with reality.

children.title: Analysis of Character Development
children.teaser: Students better understand the narrator’s interaction with Bell through his interaction with a former student.

children.title: Unit Assessment:  Supporting Analysis with Evidence
children.teaser: Students compose a multi-paragraph essay to demonstrate their understanding of the text’s central ideas.

children.title: I Won't Let Her Change Me
children.teaser: Students solidify skills of close reading, vocabulary acquisition, participation in discussions, and evidence collection.

children.title: Analyzing the Relationship with Mom
children.teaser: Students listen to a reading of “Rules of the Game”, analyzing interactions of the characters.

children.title: Developing a Central Idea
children.teaser: Students analyze the development of Waverly Jong, focusing on the significance of the chessboard.

children.title: Expectations
children.teaser: Students continue their analysis of Waverly’s development, making inferences about shifting expectations placed on her.

children.title: Climactic Confrontation: What Interactions Suggest about Larger Relationships
children.teaser: Students complete their close reading of this chapter, analyzing the cumulative development of Waverly's character.

children.title: Evolution of Central Conflict
children.teaser: Students analyze the cumulative development of Waverly’s character, considering the development of central ideas.

children.title: Eavesdropping's Impact on Point of View
children.teaser: Students continue their exploration of Jing-mei’s interactions with other characters.

children.title: Turning Points
children.teaser: Students explore interwoven thematic threads and storytelling as a mode of interaction between the characters.

children.title: Reflections on Expectations and Identity
children.teaser: Students focus on storytelling as an integral mode of interaction between the characters of Tan’s text.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Evidence-Based Claims
children.teaser: Students present an analysis of the development of a central idea in “Two Kinds.”

children.title: Father and Son
children.teaser: Students begin Friday Night Lights and how Winchell’s relationships influence his self-perception.

children.title: Using the Words of Others to Advance Our Agendas
children.teaser: Students think critically about Bissinger’s point of view and purpose, analyzing his portrayal of Odessa.

children.title: Expectations and Identity
children.teaser: Students analyze social factors at work and how memory and time function within this community.

children.title: The Season Opener: Identity, Expectations, and Tradition
children.teaser: Students consider how Bissinger structures the actions of players to reflect social pressures and expectations.

children.title: Unit Assessment: Relationships Between Children and their Parents
children.teaser: Students demonstrate a cumulative understanding of both texts in response to an assessment prompt.

children.title: Rhetoric and Word Choice to Develop Ideas and Claims
children.teaser: Students read, discuss, and analyze poems and informational texts .

children.title: The Cup of Endurance Runs Over
children.teaser: Students read Martin Luther King’s “Letter From A Birmingham Jail” and three short poems.

children.title: The Impact of Words
children.teaser: Students analyze the impact of specific words or phrases in the opening of King’s letter.

children.title: Analyzing How King Does It: Unfolding the Reasons
children.teaser: Students analyze the impact of King’s figurative language and word choices.

children.title: Racial Injustice and the Validity of the Argument
children.teaser: Students analyze the validity of King’s argument about racial injustice and why action is necessary.

children.title: Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students analyze methods of rhetoric, such as descriptive language, appeals to conscience, and rhetorical questions.

children.title: Delineating the Argument
children.teaser: Students analyze the letter to delineate King’s argument and claims, assessing his supporting evidence.

children.title: Different Authors, Different Times, and the Truth About Oppression
children.teaser: Students analyze Shamlu’s poem, exploring his use of figurative language and word connotations.

children.title: Delineating and Discussing the Argument
children.teaser: Students delineate King’s argument, assessing the validity of his reasoning through discussion of the text.

children.title: Using Rhetoric to Advance Argument around Civil Disobedience
children.teaser: Students analyze these paragraphs, determining King’s purpose and use of rhetoric to further that purpose.

children.title: A Shift in the Argument
children.teaser: Students explore how King develops his claims and analyze the shift in his argument.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Rhetoric and Word Choice
children.teaser: Students write a multi-paragraph essay addressing how rhetoric and word choice advance King’s purpose.

children.title: Advancing the Purpose
children.teaser: Students analyze how King appeals to his addressees and uses rhetoric to advance his criticism.

children.title: Refining His Claim
children.teaser: Students analyze how King refines his claim about himself through evidence-based discussion.

children.title: Images of Freedom Across Time and Place
children.teaser: Students explore how Tagore begins to develop a central idea through specific textual details.

children.title: The Church's Position
children.teaser: Students discuss how King unfolds his analysis and how he orders his points.

children.title: Ideas That Refine Ideas
children.teaser: Students analyze how King develops and refines earlier ideas through evidence-based discussion.

children.title: Rhetoric and Purpose
children.teaser: Students explore King’s rhetoric and the placement of the passage to advance his purpose.

children.title: Choosing His Words Wisely
children.teaser: Students read the closing of King’s letter, determining his purpose and his use of rhetoric.

children.title: How the Conclusion Refines the Body
children.teaser: Students analyze how King refines ideas he introduced and developed earlier in the letter.

children.title: How Walker and King Convey Ideas
children.teaser: Students analyze Walker’s poem, considering how it develops ideas similar to those in King’s letter.

children.title: Unit Assessment:  Refining Claims to Advance One's Purpose
children.teaser: Students explore King’s purpose for writing the letter and the claims he makes.

children.title: No Flies Into A Closed Mouth
children.teaser: Students engage with Julia Alvarez’s autobiographical essay, “A Genetics of Justice.”

children.title: Unfolding a Series of Ideas
children.teaser: Students read the opening of Alvarez’s essay, analyzing how she unfolds a series of ideas.

children.title: Who is Trujillo?
children.teaser: Students read two texts, analyzing the development of ideas across two mediums.

children.title: How Events Shape a Central Idea
children.teaser: Students analyze how the events that Alvarez unfolds develop an idea central to the text.

children.title: Recreating the Vision of Trauma and Freedom
children.teaser: Students explore how Alvarez develops central ideas of trauma and freedom through her mother’s experiences.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Tracing the Development of a Claim
children.teaser: Students craft an essay identifying Alvarez’s claim and how she develops this claim.

children.title: Refining Ideas: Trauma and Silence
children.teaser: Students explore how Alvarez introduces ideas of trauma and silence, demonstrating their learning.

children.title: Ideas Refine Ideas
children.teaser: Students engage in a discussion determining how ideas from paragraphs 20-22 refine earlier ideas.

children.title: The Details Shape the Meaning
children.teaser: Students explore how Alvarez uses detail to shape and refine central ideas.

children.title: Choice
children.teaser: Students explore how portions of the text develop and refine Alvarez’s ideas and claims.

children.title: Unit Assessment: No flies fly into a closed mouth.
children.teaser: Students craft an essay analyzing how one sentence develops and refines an idea.

children.title: To Lift Men Everywhere To A Higher Standard Of Life
children.teaser: Students examine documents that use rhetoric to further specific claims related to human rights.

children.title: Understanding the Ideas and Claims
children.teaser: Students explore the ideas and claims introduced and analyze how they are developed and refined.

children.title: Considering the Argument
children.teaser: Students read Eleanor Roosevelt and consider her argument, analyzing her supporting claims, evidence, and reasoning.

children.title: Analyzing the Claim
children.teaser: Students engage in discussion to analyze how Roosevelt develops and refines her claim.

children.title: Using Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students read and examine how Roosevelt’s use of rhetoric works to persuade the Assembly.

children.title: Using Rhetoric to Advance Purpose
children.teaser: Students listen to Malala Yousafzai’s address, analyzing her use of rhetoric to advance her purpose.

children.title: Refining Ideas within a Speech
children.teaser: Students analyze how Yousafzai develops and refine ideas that were introduced earlier in her speech.

children.title: Unit Assessment: A Common Claim
children.teaser: Students demonstrate understanding of the arguments and common claims presented in all three unit texts.

children.title: Researching Multiple Perspectives to Develop a Position
children.teaser: Students engage in an inquiry-based, iterative process for research.

children.title: Using Seed Texts as Springboards to Research
children.teaser: Students build prior skills and focus on annotation, and an independent analysis of texts.

children.title: Inquiry-Based Research Introduction
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the focus of the module: building evidence-based arguments through inquiry-based research.

children.title: Unfolding the Events
children.teaser: Students analyze the text paying specific attention to how Skloot unfolds the events and ideas.

children.title: Language and Word Choice Surfacing an Issue
children.teaser: Students begin the research process by learning how to surface issues and pose inquiry questions.

children.title: Generating, Refining, and Selecting Inquiry Questions
children.teaser: They continue to generate, refine, and select inquiry questions to guide their research.

children.title: Supporting a Claim
children.teaser: Students analyze how Skloot supports a perspective through description and use of language.

children.title: Synthesizing Findings and Supporting a Claim
children.teaser: Students evaluate evidence that Skloot uses to support her claim, assessing its relevancy and sufficiency.

children.title: History of Unethical Medical Practice and the African-America Community
children.teaser: Students analyze how Skloot unfolds relevant evidence to support the perspective of the Lacks family.

children.title: Taking Advantage
children.teaser: Students analyze the text, working to identify a central idea based on specific details.

children.title: How the Pieces Create the Whole
children.teaser: Students refine specific ideas that have emerged in the larger text.

children.title: John Moore and Henrietta Lacks
children.teaser: Students compare the stories through text analysis, learning about the concept of perspective.

children.title: How Multiple Perspectives Develop a Picture
children.teaser: Students consider how the information in this excerpt impacts their developing understanding of tissue ownership.

children.title: Two Encounters, Two Perspectives
children.teaser: Students read about Skloot’s encounter Lacks’ son and a visit to meet a Hopkins scientist.

children.title: Collecting Evidence to Develop Claims
children.teaser: Students focus on understanding claims and evidence in informational text, developing claims for argument writing.

children.title: Claims and Counter-Claims
children.teaser: Students write a paragraph synthesizing their understanding of supporting evidence and identifying a claim.

children.title: Unit Assessment Part 1: Analyze Central Idea; Part 2: Reflect on Research Process
children.teaser: Reflecting on the research process, students write about areas of investigation emerging from the book.

children.title: Engaging in an Inquiry-Based, Iterative Research Process to Write Arguments
children.teaser: Students continue to learn how to use the inquiry-based research process.

children.title: The Research Portfolio
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the research unit, constructing a Research Portfolio for previously conducted research.

children.title: Inquiry Questions
children.teaser: Students learn how to craft specific inquiry questions for their selected research topic/area of investigation.

children.title: Conducting Effective and Efficient Research
children.teaser: Students learn how to select inquiry questions and use key words to conduct effective research.

children.title: Reading and Annotating Relevant Sources
children.teaser: Students learn to read important sources for selected inquiry questions, using annotation and note taking.

children.title: Evaluating Evidence-Based Argument
children.teaser: Students evaluate evidence-based arguments through identifying components of a compelling argument and assessing their effectiveness.

children.title: Constructing a Frame to Guide Research
children.teaser: Students group their inquiry questions thematically, establish a problem-based question, and formally plan their research.

children.title: Sustained and Independent Research Day 1
children.teaser: Students begin conducting searches independently using the Research Frame and associated search tools.

children.title: Sustained and Independent Research Day 2
children.teaser: Students focus on determining if the research surfaced is sufficient, adjusting the search accordingly.

children.title: Sustained and Independent Research Day 3
children.teaser: Students continue to research independently, using the steps taught previously.

children.title: Initial Claims
children.teaser: Students complete Forming Evidence-Based Claims Tools for all inquiry paths on the Research Frame.

children.title: Building on Claims
children.teaser: Students develop comprehensive claims about each inquiry path in the Research Frame.

children.title: Forming Counterclaims
children.teaser: Students choose one claim from the previous lesson to form a counterclaim identifying supporting evidence.

children.title: Evidence-Based Perspective
children.teaser: Students write an Evidence-Based Perspective and based upon the research from this unit.

children.title: Synthesizing Research and Argument Through the Writing Process
children.teaser: Students analyze the sources collected for their Research Portfolios, delving into them throughout the writing process.

children.title: Determining, Organizing, and Analyzing Evidence
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the process of drafting research-based argument papers, completing the Outline Tool.

children.title: Counterclaims
children.teaser: They address the strengths and limitations of their central claim, developing support for a counterclaim.

children.title: Integrating Information and Avoiding Plagiarism
children.teaser: Students learn how to integrate citation information to follow a standard format for citation.

children.title: Peer Review, In-text Citation, Effective Introduction
children.teaser: Students then learn about the purpose and components of an effective introduction.

children.title: Transitional Words, Relationships between Claims, Counterclaims, and Evidence
children.teaser: Students focus on building cohesion and clarity as they draft their research-based argument papers.

children.title: Closing Statements
children.teaser: Students craft concluding statements that further support the argument and connect sections of the text.

children.title: Formal Style, Objective Tone
children.teaser: Students learn how to use formal style and objective tone when writing their papers.

children.title: Peer Review, Teacher Conferencing
children.teaser: Students learn how to revise for formal tone and conventions in argument writing.

children.title: Fun with Grammar
children.teaser: Students learn about semicolons to join independent clauses and colons to introduce quotes or lists.

children.title: Peer Review and Constructive Feedback
children.teaser: Students offer constructive feedback to their classmates about their entire research-based argument papers.

children.title: Finalizing the Paper
children.teaser: Students finalize their research-based argument papers, editing and rewriting as necessary.

children.title: Craft, Structure, and Development of Characters and Ideas
children.teaser: Students read, discuss, and analyze nonfiction and dramatic texts.

children.title: Once in a While, Something Slips
children.teaser: Students analyze how White unfolds and draws connections between key events and ideas.

children.title: Personal Narrative Essay
children.teaser: Students analyze specific word choices in the first section “Death of a Pig.”

children.title: Analysis of the Tragic Trajectory
children.teaser: Students identifying and analyzing the development of a central idea in the text.

children.title: Structural Choices
children.teaser: Students analyze the third section of E. B. White’s “Death of a Pig.”

children.title: Impact of Words
children.teaser: Students consider the cumulative impact of words and phrases on meaning in the story.

children.title: Structure
children.teaser: Students evaluate White’s story, considering his use of parallel structure and varied grammatical phrases.

children.title: Unit Assessment:  "Once and a while something slips"
children.teaser: Students discuss White’s development of the idea “once in a while something slips”.

children.title: Editing the Essay
children.teaser: Students peer-review and edit their End-of-Unit Assessment for correct punctuation, spelling, and sentence structure.

children.title: “There’s no art / To find the mind’s construction in the face”
children.teaser: Student continue to practice reading closely, annotating text, collaborative discussion, and evidence-based writing.

children.title: The Three Witches
children.teaser: Students begin their study of Macbeth by reading Act 1.1 and 1.2

children.title: Fate vs. Agency; Appearance vs. Reality
children.teaser: Students read Act 1.3, focusing on the emergence of central ideas in this scene.

children.title: Lady Macbeth is Anything But
children.teaser: Students read Act 1.5, in which Lady Macbeth considers murdering Duncan.

children.title: The Macbeth's Relationship
children.teaser: Students read Act 1.6 and 1.7, examining Macbeth’s soliloquy and his interactions with his wife.

children.title: A Killing Mood
children.teaser: Students read Act 2.1, in which Macbeth prepares to kill Duncan.

children.title: Waiting for the Deed to be Done
children.teaser: Students read Act 2.2, in which Macbeth is horrified by having killed Duncan.

children.title: Appearance vs. Reality: Blaming the Wrong Guys
children.teaser: Students read Act 2.3, in which Duncan’s murder is discovered.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment:  How Structural Choices Create Mystery, Tension, Surprise
children.teaser: Students craft an essay discussing how structural choices create an effect of mystery, tension, surprise.

children.title: Foul Play
children.teaser: Students read Act 3.1, in which Macbeth hires murderers to kill Banquo and his son.

children.title: Nefarious Deeds Precipitate Tragedy
children.teaser: Students read and analyze Act 3.2 of Macbeth.

children.title: Development of Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students read Act 3.4, in which only Macbeth sees Banquo’s ghost at a feast.

children.title: Witches Advance the Plot
children.teaser: Students read Act 4.1, in which Three Witches who tell Macbeth of the future.

children.title: Commissioning Murder and Figurative Language
children.teaser: Students read Act 4.2, in which Lady Macduff is slain by Murderers commissioned by Macbeth.

children.title: Macbeth's Character is Developed by Malcom and Macduff
children.teaser: Students read Act 4.3, in which Macduff tries to convince Malcolm to join him.

children.title: Why does Shakespeare Show us Before They Tell Him?
children.teaser: Students read Act 4.3, in which Ross tells Macduff of his family’s murder.

children.title: Descent into Madness
children.teaser: Students read Act 5.1, when Lady Macbeth sleepwalks, lamenting the murders she and Macbeth committed.

children.title: Figurative LanguagePreparing for a Dramatic Reading
children.teaser: Students read Act 5.2 and 5.3, in which the Thanes desert Macbeth.

children.title: Collaborative Discussion and Rehearsal
children.teaser: Students read Act 5.4, 5.5, and 5.6: both sides prepare for battle; Lady Macbeth dies.

children.title: Not Born of Woman
children.teaser: Students read Act 5.7 and 5.8, in which Macbeth is defeated and killed by Macduff.

children.title: Group Performance
children.teaser: Students use choral reading techniques to interpret self-selected scenes from Shakespeare’s Macbeth.

children.title: Who is at Fault?
children.teaser: Students begin to question which character bears primary responsibility for the tragedy.

children.title: Assessment: Who Bears the Most Responsibility for the Tragedy?
children.teaser: Students present an argument about which character bears the responsibility for the tragedy of Macbeth.

children.title: Oral Presentations
children.teaser: In this optional lesson students present their arguments as oral presentations to small peer groups.

children.title: The Witches in Art
children.teaser: Students prepare to consider treatments of Macbeth in the visual arts through various activities.

children.title: How Macbeth Influences International Films
children.teaser: Students analyze Throne of Blood, comparing the opening scenes to Acts 1.1 - 1.3.

children.title: Macbeth in Film
children.teaser: Students compare the Royal Shakespeare Company’s production Acts 1.1 through 1.3 to the original text.

children.title: Comparing Film Interpretations
children.teaser: Students explore the significance of how directorial choices emphasize different elements of a drama.

children.title: The Nature of Princes
children.teaser: Students ask: "Would Macbeth be considered a successful prince under Machiavelli’s rules?"

children.title: Mercy and Cruelty: Is it Better to Be Loved or Feared?
children.teaser: Students identify the central ideas of the values of mercy and cruelty for a prince.

children.title: Point of View and Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students discuss Machiavelli’s point of view in this text and his use of rhetoric.

children.title: Analyzing how Machiavelli Develops His Ideas
children.teaser: Students identify common central ideas of morality, ambition, and the relationship between appearance and reality.

children.title: Looking at How He Uses Words
children.teaser: Students identify quotes to analyze how specific phrases refine and develop claims and central ideas.

children.title: What would Machiavelli Think?
children.teaser: Students consider if Machiavelli would deem the fictional character of Macbeth a successful prince.

children.title: Argument, Informative, and Narrative Writing
children.teaser: Students explore argument, informative, and narrative writing.

children.title: Argument Writing
children.teaser: Students are introduced to argument writing by examining argument models and writing their own papers.

children.title: Introduction to Argument Writing
children.teaser: Students are introduced to argument writing, beginning with the writing process and annotation.

children.title: Effective Argument Writing: Purpose and Audience
children.teaser: Students examine a second argument model, focusing in particular on purpose and audience.

children.title: Argument Writing: Analyzing the Prompt
children.teaser: Students begin to write a multi-paragraph argument in response to a prompt.

children.title: Argument Writing: Claims and Evidence
children.teaser: Students identify the article’s pros and cons related to screen time.

children.title: Argument Writing: More Claims and Evidence
children.teaser: Students analyze an article, recording the pros and cons they have gathered.

children.title: Argument Writing: Processing the Information
children.teaser: Students articulate their thoughts about the topic of screen time.

children.title: Argument Writing: Drafting an Outline
children.teaser: Students draft an outline that aligns with their statement of purpose.

children.title: Argument Writing: Drafting Body Paragraphs
children.teaser: Students identify elements of effective body paragraphs, then draft their own.

children.title: Argument Writing: Drafting an Introduction
children.teaser: Students examine effective introductions from the source texts, then draft their own.

children.title: Argument Writing: Drafting a Conclusion
children.teaser: Students discuss the components that make conclusions effective, then draft their own.

children.title: Argument Writing: Getting Feedback
children.teaser: Students offer constructive criticism to their classmates about their argument drafts.

children.title: Finalizing Argument Papers
children.teaser: Students edit, revise, and finalize their argument drafts.

children.title: Argument Writing: Reflecting on the Writing Process
children.teaser: Students reflect on the writing process, identifying strengths and weaknesses.

children.title: Supplemental Skills Instruction
children.teaser: Students learn discrete writing skills to improve their writing.

children.title: Integrating Evidence from Sources
children.teaser: Students learn how to integrate evidence and citations into arguments.

children.title: Audience, Style, and Tone
children.teaser: Students learn how to identify and use formal style and objective tone.

children.title: Working with Words
children.teaser: Students learn how to incorporate precise and specific words to improve their arguments.

children.title: Cohesion and Flow
children.teaser: Students learn to identify and use varied syntax and transitional words and phrases.

children.title: Varying Sentence Length
children.teaser: Students learn how to combine and split sentences to improve the clarity of their writing.

children.title: Ensuring Sentence Accuracy
children.teaser: Students learn how to use commas and repair sentence fragments and run-on sentences.

children.title: Adding Variety and Interest
children.teaser: Students learn how to incorporate parallel structure and varied phrases into their writing.

children.title: Informative Writing
children.teaser: Students are introduced to informative writing by examining argument models and writing their own papers.

children.title: Introduction to Informative Writing
children.teaser: Students are introduced to informative writing, beginning with the writing process and annotation.

children.title: Effective Informative Writing: Purpose and Audience
children.teaser: Students examine a second informative model, focusing in particular on purpose and audience.

children.title: Informative Writing: Analyzing the Prompt
children.teaser: Students analyze an informative writing prompt to determine the writing task.

children.title: Informative Writing: Charting Topics, Subtopics, Claims, and Evidence
children.teaser: Students review the topic and claim of the article and chart the subtopics and evidence.

children.title: Informative Writing: More Subtopics and Evidence
children.teaser: Students analyze the article and continue charting subtopics and evidence.

children.title: Informative Writing: Processing the Information
children.teaser: Students articulate their thoughts about the topic and their claim, subtopics, and evidence.

children.title: Informative Writing: Drafting an Outline
children.teaser: Students draft an outline that aligns with their statement of purpose.

children.title: Informative Writing: Drafting Body Paragraphs
children.teaser: Students identify elements of effective body paragraphs, then draft their own.

children.title: Informative Writing: Drafting an Introduction
children.teaser: Students examine effective introductions from the source texts, then draft their own.

children.title: Informative Writing: Drafting a Conclusion
children.teaser: Students discuss the components that make conclusions effective, then write their own.

children.title: Informative Writing: Getting Feedback
children.teaser: Students offer constructive criticism to their classmates about their informative drafts.

children.title: Finalizing Informative Papers
children.teaser: Students edit, revise, and finalize their informative drafts.

children.title: Informative Writing: Reflecting on the Writing Process
children.teaser: Students reflect on the writing process, identifying strengths and weaknesses.

children.title: Supplemental Skills Instruction
children.teaser: Students learn discrete writing skills to improve their writing.

children.title: Integrating Evidence from Sources
children.teaser: Students learn how to integrate evidence and citations into arguments.

children.title: Audience, Style, and Tone
children.teaser: Students learn how to identify and use formal style and objective tone.

children.title: Working with Words
children.teaser: Students learn how to incorporate precise and specific words to improve their arguments.

children.title: Cohesion and Flow
children.teaser: Students learn to identify and use varied syntax and transitional words and phrases.

children.title: Varying Sentence Length
children.teaser: Students learn how to combine and split sentences to improve the clarity of their writing.

children.title: Ensuring Sentence Accuracy
children.teaser: Students learn how to use commas and repair sentence fragments and run-on sentences.

children.title: Adding Variety and Interest
children.teaser: Students learn how to incorporate parallel structure and varied phrases into their writing.

children.title: Narrative Writing
children.teaser: Students are introduced to narrative writing by examining writing models and writing their own narrative.

children.title: Introduction to Narrative Writing
children.teaser: Students are introduced to narrative writing, beginning with the writing process and annotation

children.title: Effective Narrative Writing: Organization and Purpose
children.teaser: Students continue discussing what makes a narrative effective, focusing on organization and purpose.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Analyzing the Prompt
children.teaser: Students analyze a narrative writing prompt to determine the writing task.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Source Material
children.teaser: Students continue to examine source material to prepare for their own narrative drafts.

children.title: Narrative Writing: More Source Material
children.teaser: Students analyze written material as well as audio and video sources.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Drafting an Introduction
children.teaser: Students examine effective introductions before drafting their own.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Drafting Body Paragraphs
children.teaser: Students examine effective body paragraphs before drafting their own, focusing on descriptions and reflections.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Drafting Body Paragraphs
children.teaser: Students continue drafting their body paragraphs, focusing on pacing and dialogue.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Drafting a Conclusion
children.teaser: Students examine effective conclusions, then craft conclusions of their own.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Structural Techniques
children.teaser: Students strengthen their own narratives by using a variety of structural techniques.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Getting Feedback
children.teaser: Students offer constructive criticism to their classmates about their narrative drafts.

children.title: Finalizing Narrative Papers
children.teaser: Students review common editing symbols and finalize their narrative drafts.

children.title: Narrative Writing: Reflecting on the Writing Process
children.teaser: Students reflect on the writing process, identifying strengths and weaknesses.

children.title: Supplemental Skills Instruction
children.teaser: Students are offered direct instruction on discrete writing skills to improve narrative writing.

children.title: Working with Words
children.teaser: Students learn about using precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language.

children.title: Cohesion and Flow
children.teaser: Students learn about using varied syntax and transitional words and phrases.

children.title: Varying Sentence Length
children.teaser: Students learn how to combine and split sentences to improve the clarity of their writing.

children.title: Ensuring Sentence Accuracy
children.teaser: Students learn how to use commas and repair sentence fragments and run-on sentences.

children.title: Adding Variety and Interest
children.teaser: Students learn how to incorporate parallel structure and varied phrases into their writing.

children.title: Punctuating Dialogue
children.teaser: Students learn how to punctuate the dialogue in a narrative.

children.title: Developing Core Proficiencies Curriculum
children.teaser: These units model instruction and provide flexible materials to use and adapt for a variety of contexts.

children.title: Reading Closely for Textual Details Units
children.teaser: Grades 9-10: “Brain Gain”

children.title: At The Beginning I Was Only A Little Mass Of Possibilities.
children.teaser: Students analyze visual-based texts.

children.title: The Education Process Begins Before The Child Is Born.
children.teaser: Students read and analyze informational texts.

children.title: Never Be The Obstacle Between The Child And His Experience.
children.teaser: Never be the obstacle between the child and his experience.

children.title: The True Purpose Of Education Is To Produce Citizens
children.teaser: Students read and analyze three related texts.

children.title: A Great Equalizer Of The Conditions Of Men
children.teaser: Students learn the characteristics of an effective text-based discussion.

children.title: Making Evidence-Based Claims
children.teaser: Nobel Peace Prize Speeches of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and President Barack Obama

children.title: The Question of Our Time
children.teaser: Students learn the elements of making evidence-based claims.

children.title: An Audacious Faith
children.teaser: Students develop the ability to make evidence-based claims.

children.title: I Face The World As It Is
children.teaser: Students organize evidence to develop and expand claims.

children.title: The Peace We Seek
children.teaser: Students express evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: A Just and Lasting Peace
children.teaser: Students express global evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: Making Evidence-Based Claims about Literary Technique
children.teaser: "Because I could not stop for Death," Emily Dickinson, and "Home Burial," Robert Frost

children.title: We Drove Slowly, He Knew No Haste
children.teaser: Students learn the elements of making evidence-based claims.

children.title: The Dews Drew Quivering And Chill
children.teaser: Students develop the ability to make evidence-based claims.

children.title: Looking Back Over Her Shoulder At Some Fear
children.teaser: Students organize evidence to develop and expand claims.

children.title: Friends Make Pretense Of Following To The Grave
children.teaser: Students express evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: You Won't Go Now.  You're Crying.  Close The Door.
children.teaser: Students express global evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: Researching to Deepen Understanding
children.teaser: Grades 9-10: Research Topic Repository - Music and Technology

children.title: Initiating Inquiry
children.teaser: By the end of Part 1, students will have identified an Area of Investigation and developed Inquiry Questions.

children.title: Gathering Information
children.teaser: By the end of Part 2, students will have assessed the main common sources and gathered notes about the information in the texts.

children.title: Deepening Understanding
children.teaser: By the end of Part 3, students will have a series of evidence-based claims addressing their Inquiry Questions.

children.title: Finalizing Inquiry
children.teaser: By the end of Part 4, students will have an analyzed body of research addressing their Inquiry Questions from which to develop and communicate an evidence- based perspective on the Area of Investigation.

children.title: Developing And Communicating An Evidence-Based Perspective
children.teaser: By the end of Part 5, students will have an organized body of research and have written an evidence-based perspective on the Area of Investigation.

children.title: Building Evidence-Based Arguments
children.teaser: “The government does not need a search warrant to obtain your personal documents if you have already shared them with somebody else.”

children.title: We can’t have one hundred percent securityand one hundred percent privacy.
children.teaser: Students understand an issue as a context for various perspectives, positions, and arguments.

children.title: We're dealing with terrorists who operate by highly sophisticated methods and technologies,some of which were not even available when our existing laws were written.
children.teaser: Students analyze the position, evidence, and perspective of arguments.

children.title: The National Security Agency and the FBI are tapping directly into the central servers of nine leading U.S. Internet companies, extracting audio and video chats, photographs, e-mails, documents, and connection logs that enable analysts to track foreign targets
children.teaser: Students evaluate arguments and synthesize what they have learned.

children.title: It is hereby ordered that, the Custodian of Records shall produce to the National Security Agency upon service of this Order...all call detail records or “telephony metadata” created by Verizon for communications.
children.teaser: Students establish evidence-based claims as a premises for a logical argument.

children.title: What do I know?
children.teaser: For students, writing is a key means of asserting and defending claims, showing what they know about a subject, and conveying what they have experienced, imagined, thought, and felt.
